Key Arguments: The bill lacks sufficient checks, balances, and transparency in ACMA's actions regarding free speech and misinformation/disinformation.
The legislation is out of step with international standards on freedom of speech, such as the UN Declaration of Human Rights.
The bill is vague in defining 'harmful' speech, which could lead to the silencing of legitimate speech and criticism.
Digital service providers are coerced into silencing content due to the vague definitions, which threatens freedom of speech.
The government exempts itself from the rules it imposes on the public, leading to potential political control over public discourse.
The bill could breach privacy laws by compelling digital platforms to provide information on misinformation/disinformation.
There is a lack of scrutiny, accountability, oversight, and transparency to prevent misuse of censorship powers.
Penalties for non-compliance are excessive and could lead to the shutdown of free speech on digital platforms.
Notable Quotes: Transparency and control are desperately lacking in the bill.
This bill exerts what I call an over-reach of government control on what is considered misinformation or disinformation.
The vagueness of the legislation will coerce digital service providers into silencing everything that could see them breach the law.
This is self-defeating and borders on political control of what citizens can say or think on public issues.
